Dispute_Type: Jurisdictional dispute over human rights complaint
Legal_Issue: Whether the CHRC has jurisdiction to hear a sexual harassment complaint against the CSA
Evidence_Assessment: Contractual relationship involving personal service, remuneration, and control
Decision_Outcome: CHRC has jurisdiction to hear the complaint
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show jurisdictional error
Legal_Rule: 'Employment' under CHRA includes contractual service relationships
Procedural_Issue: Procedural fairness in CHRC's decision to accept complaint
Grounds_for_Claim: Sexual harassment during participation in CSA and IBMP study
Decision_Maker: Canadian Human Rights Commission (CHRC); Federal Court on review
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: No breach of procedural fairness found
Key_Evidence_Considered: Service contract between Lapierre and CSA
Legal_Framework: Administrative law and human rights law
Applicant_Challenge: Attorney General of Canada challenged CHRC’s jurisdiction
Defendant_Response: CSA argued no employer-employee relationship existed
Outcome: Complaint allowed to proceed before CHRC
Legal_Provision_Cited: Canadian Human Rights Act, definition of 'employment'
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Lack of employment relationship as defined by CHRA
Applicable_Process: Filing of complaint with CHRC, followed by judicial review
Governing_Rule: Broad statutory definition of 'employment' includes contractual service providers
